items.title: I can identify the components of an atom and use standard nuclear notation
items.what: Atoms consist of protons and neutrons (nucleons) in the nucleus, with electrons orbiting outside. The notation A/Z X shows mass number A (protons + neutrons) and atomic number Z (protons only).
items.why: This notation is used universally in nuclear physics to identify specific isotopes and track changes during nuclear reactions.
items.example: Uranium-238 is written as ²³⁸₉₂U, meaning it has 92 protons and 238 - 92 = 146 neutrons.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Stability and Forces
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores why some nuclei are stable while others undergo radioactive decay. It covers the three fundamental forces at work inside the nucleus and how the balance between these forces determines nuclear stability.
subtopic.why: Understanding nuclear stability explains why certain isotopes are radioactive and others are not. This knowledge is essential for understanding radioactive decay, nuclear energy, and why elements heavier than lead are all unstable.

items.title: I can explain what isotopes are and how they differ from each other
items.what: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons. They have identical chemical properties but different physical properties.
items.why: Understanding isotopes is crucial because some isotopes of an element are stable while others are radioactive, which determines their behaviour and applications.
items.example: Hydrogen has three isotopes: hydrogen-1 (1 proton, 0 neutrons), deuterium (1 proton, 1 neutron), and tritium (1 proton, 2 neutrons). Only tritium is radioactive.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Stability and Forces
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores why some nuclei are stable while others undergo radioactive decay. It covers the three fundamental forces at work inside the nucleus and how the balance between these forces determines nuclear stability.
subtopic.why: Understanding nuclear stability explains why certain isotopes are radioactive and others are not. This knowledge is essential for understanding radioactive decay, nuclear energy, and why elements heavier than lead are all unstable.

items.title: I can describe how the neutron-to-proton ratio affects nuclear stability
items.what: Small stable nuclei have roughly equal numbers of protons and neutrons (1:1 ratio). Larger stable nuclei need more neutrons than protons (up to 1.5:1 ratio) to remain stable within the belt of stability.
items.why: This ratio determines whether an isotope will be stable or radioactive. Isotopes outside the belt of stability will undergo decay to reach a more stable configuration.
items.example: Helium-4 is stable with 2 protons and 2 neutrons (1:1 ratio), while mercury-200 is stable with 80 protons and 120 neutrons (1.5:1 ratio).

subtopic.name: Nuclear Stability and Forces
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores why some nuclei are stable while others undergo radioactive decay. It covers the three fundamental forces at work inside the nucleus and how the balance between these forces determines nuclear stability.
subtopic.why: Understanding nuclear stability explains why certain isotopes are radioactive and others are not. This knowledge is essential for understanding radioactive decay, nuclear energy, and why elements heavier than lead are all unstable.

items.title: I can explain how electrostatic forces act between protons in the nucleus
items.what: Protons in the nucleus experience extremely strong electrostatic repulsion because they are positively charged and very close together (about 10⁻¹⁵ m apart). This force acts over infinite range and tries to push the nucleus apart.
items.why: The electrostatic repulsion between protons is the destabilising force in nuclei. Understanding this explains why larger nuclei with more protons become increasingly unstable.
items.example: Two protons in a helium nucleus are only 10⁻¹⁵ m apart, creating an enormous repulsive force that should blow the nucleus apart, yet it remains stable.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Stability and Forces
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores why some nuclei are stable while others undergo radioactive decay. It covers the three fundamental forces at work inside the nucleus and how the balance between these forces determines nuclear stability.
subtopic.why: Understanding nuclear stability explains why certain isotopes are radioactive and others are not. This knowledge is essential for understanding radioactive decay, nuclear energy, and why elements heavier than lead are all unstable.

items.title: I can explain how the strong nuclear force holds the nucleus together
items.what: The strong nuclear force is an attractive force between all nucleons (protons and neutrons). It is about 100 times stronger than the electrostatic force but only acts over very short distances (about 10⁻¹⁵ m).
items.why: This force overcomes electrostatic repulsion at short range, keeping the nucleus intact. Its short range explains why very large nuclei become unstable.
items.example: In a helium-4 nucleus, each nucleon attracts its neighbours via the strong force, which is strong enough at this tiny distance to overcome the proton-proton repulsion.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Stability and Forces
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores why some nuclei are stable while others undergo radioactive decay. It covers the three fundamental forces at work inside the nucleus and how the balance between these forces determines nuclear stability.
subtopic.why: Understanding nuclear stability explains why certain isotopes are radioactive and others are not. This knowledge is essential for understanding radioactive decay, nuclear energy, and why elements heavier than lead are all unstable.

items.title: I can describe the role of the weak nuclear force in beta decay
items.what: The weak nuclear force is responsible for transforming neutrons into protons (and vice versa) during beta decay. It acts over an extremely short range (about 10⁻¹⁸ m).
items.why: This force explains how nuclei can change their neutron-to-proton ratio to become more stable, which is the mechanism behind beta radiation.
items.example: When carbon-14 decays, the weak force transforms a neutron into a proton, emitting a beta particle and converting the atom into nitrogen-14.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Stability and Forces
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores why some nuclei are stable while others undergo radioactive decay. It covers the three fundamental forces at work inside the nucleus and how the balance between these forces determines nuclear stability.
subtopic.why: Understanding nuclear stability explains why certain isotopes are radioactive and others are not. This knowledge is essential for understanding radioactive decay, nuclear energy, and why elements heavier than lead are all unstable.

items.title: I can interpret a binding energy curve to compare nuclear stability
items.what: Binding energy is the energy needed to split a nucleus into individual nucleons. The binding energy per nucleon varies with mass number, reaching a maximum around iron-56, which makes it the most stable nucleus.
items.why: The binding energy curve explains why both fusion (joining light nuclei) and fission (splitting heavy nuclei) can release energy, as both processes move toward iron-56.
items.example: Iron-56 has a binding energy of 8.8 MeV per nucleon. Uranium-238 has about 7.6 MeV per nucleon, so splitting uranium releases energy as the products move toward the iron peak.

subtopic.name: Nuclear Stability and Forces
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores why some nuclei are stable while others undergo radioactive decay. It covers the three fundamental forces at work inside the nucleus and how the balance between these forces determines nuclear stability.
subtopic.why: Understanding nuclear stability explains why certain isotopes are radioactive and others are not. This knowledge is essential for understanding radioactive decay, nuclear energy, and why elements heavier than lead are all unstable.

items.title: I can describe the composition and properties of alpha radiation
items.what: Alpha particles consist of 2 protons and 2 neutrons (a helium-4 nucleus). They have a charge of +2, travel at about 10% the speed of light, have high ionising ability, and very low penetrating power.
items.why: Alpha radiation is highly damaging to cells but easily stopped, making it dangerous if inhaled or ingested but relatively safe from external sources.
items.example: Alpha particles from uranium-238 travel about 30,000 km/s and can be stopped by a sheet of paper or a few centimetres of air.

subtopic.name: Types of Nuclear Radiation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the three main types of radiation emitted by unstable nuclei: alpha particles, beta particles (both negative and positive), and gamma rays. Each type has distinct properties that determine its behaviour and applications.
subtopic.why: Understanding the different types of radiation is essential for predicting how they interact with matter, assessing their potential hazards, and selecting appropriate shielding and applications in medicine and industry.

items.title: I can describe the composition and properties of beta radiation
items.what: Beta-minus (β⁻) particles are high-speed electrons, and beta-plus (β⁺) particles are positrons. They have a charge of ±1, travel at up to 90% the speed of light, have medium ionising ability, and medium penetrating power.
items.why: Beta radiation can penetrate skin but is stopped by a few millimetres of aluminium, making it useful for applications like thickness gauging and medical treatments.
items.example: Beta particles can penetrate up to 1 metre of air and can be stopped by aluminium sheeting about 2 mm thick.

subtopic.name: Types of Nuclear Radiation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the three main types of radiation emitted by unstable nuclei: alpha particles, beta particles (both negative and positive), and gamma rays. Each type has distinct properties that determine its behaviour and applications.
subtopic.why: Understanding the different types of radiation is essential for predicting how they interact with matter, assessing their potential hazards, and selecting appropriate shielding and applications in medicine and industry.

items.title: I can describe the properties of gamma radiation
items.what: Gamma rays are high-energy photons with no charge and no mass. They travel at the speed of light, have low ionising ability, but very high penetrating power, requiring dense materials like lead or concrete to absorb them.
items.why: Gamma radiation can penetrate the human body, making it useful for medical imaging and cancer treatment but also the most dangerous type for external exposure.
items.example: Gamma rays require about 5 cm of lead or 1 metre of concrete to absorb 97% of the radiation.

subtopic.name: Types of Nuclear Radiation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the three main types of radiation emitted by unstable nuclei: alpha particles, beta particles (both negative and positive), and gamma rays. Each type has distinct properties that determine its behaviour and applications.
subtopic.why: Understanding the different types of radiation is essential for predicting how they interact with matter, assessing their potential hazards, and selecting appropriate shielding and applications in medicine and industry.

items.title: I can write nuclear decay equations for alpha decay
items.what: In alpha decay, a nucleus emits an alpha particle (⁴₂He), reducing its mass number by 4 and atomic number by 2. The sum of mass numbers and atomic numbers must balance on both sides of the equation.
items.why: Writing decay equations allows us to predict what new element forms when a radioactive nucleus decays and track the conservation of mass and charge.
items.example: Uranium-238 alpha decay: ²³⁸₉₂U → ²³⁴₉₀Th + ⁴₂He. The mass numbers (238 = 234 + 4) and atomic numbers (92 = 90 + 2) both balance.

subtopic.name: Types of Nuclear Radiation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the three main types of radiation emitted by unstable nuclei: alpha particles, beta particles (both negative and positive), and gamma rays. Each type has distinct properties that determine its behaviour and applications.
subtopic.why: Understanding the different types of radiation is essential for predicting how they interact with matter, assessing their potential hazards, and selecting appropriate shielding and applications in medicine and industry.

items.title: I can write nuclear decay equations for beta decay
items.what: In β⁻ decay, a neutron becomes a proton, emitting an electron (⁰₋₁e). In β⁺ decay, a proton becomes a neutron, emitting a positron (⁰₊₁e). Mass number stays the same while atomic number changes by 1.
items.why: Beta decay equations show how nuclei adjust their neutron-to-proton ratio to become more stable without changing their total number of nucleons.
items.example: Carbon-14 beta-minus decay: ¹⁴₆C → ¹⁴₇N + ⁰₋₁e. The mass number stays at 14, and the atomic number increases from 6 to 7.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the three main types of radiation emitted by unstable nuclei: alpha particles, beta particles (both negative and positive), and gamma rays. Each type has distinct properties that determine its behaviour and applications.
subtopic.why: Understanding the different types of radiation is essential for predicting how they interact with matter, assessing their potential hazards, and selecting appropriate shielding and applications in medicine and industry.

items.title: I can write nuclear decay equations for gamma emission
items.what: Gamma emission occurs when an excited nucleus releases energy as a photon (⁰₀γ) without changing its mass number or atomic number. The asterisk (*) indicates an excited nuclear state.
items.why: Gamma emission often accompanies alpha or beta decay as the nucleus settles into a lower energy state, which is important for understanding decay processes.
items.example: Excited magnesium-24: ²⁴₁₂Mg* → ²⁴₁₂Mg + ⁰₀γ. Both mass number and atomic number remain unchanged.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the three main types of radiation emitted by unstable nuclei: alpha particles, beta particles (both negative and positive), and gamma rays. Each type has distinct properties that determine its behaviour and applications.
subtopic.why: Understanding the different types of radiation is essential for predicting how they interact with matter, assessing their potential hazards, and selecting appropriate shielding and applications in medicine and industry.

items.title: I can explain why radioactive decay is described as random
items.what: It is impossible to predict when any individual nucleus will decay. However, with large numbers of nuclei, we can statistically predict the overall decay rate using the half-life concept.
items.why: Understanding the random nature of decay explains why we use statistical measures like half-life rather than trying to predict individual decay events.
items.example: One gram of uranium-238 contains 2.6 × 10²¹ atoms. While we cannot predict which specific atom will decay next, we can predict that half will decay over 4.5 billion years.

subtopic.name: Radioactive Decay and Half-Life
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the random nature of radioactive decay and how the half-life concept allows us to predict the behaviour of large numbers of radioactive nuclei. It includes mathematical modelling using whole half-lives.
subtopic.why: Half-life calculations are essential for applications ranging from carbon dating ancient objects to selecting appropriate radioisotopes for medical procedures and managing nuclear waste safely.

items.title: I can define half-life and explain what it represents
items.what: Half-life (t½) is the time taken for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay. It is constant for each isotope and unaffected by temperature, pressure, or chemical environment.
items.why: Half-life is a fundamental property of each radioisotope that determines its applications, from short half-lives for medical tracers to long half-lives for geological dating.
items.example: Technetium-99m has a half-life of 6.0 hours, meaning after 6 hours, only half the original technetium-99m remains. After 12 hours, only one-quarter remains.

subtopic.name: Radioactive Decay and Half-Life
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the random nature of radioactive decay and how the half-life concept allows us to predict the behaviour of large numbers of radioactive nuclei. It includes mathematical modelling using whole half-lives.
subtopic.why: Half-life calculations are essential for applications ranging from carbon dating ancient objects to selecting appropriate radioisotopes for medical procedures and managing nuclear waste safely.

items.title: I can calculate the amount of radioactive material remaining after whole half-lives
items.what: The formula N = N₀ × (½)ⁿ calculates the remaining amount, where N₀ is the original amount and n is the number of half-lives elapsed. After each half-life, the amount halves.
items.why: This calculation is essential for determining how long radioactive materials remain dangerous, planning medical treatments, and dating ancient objects.
items.example: If you start with 100 g of a substance with a 10-day half-life, after 30 days (3 half-lives): N = 100 × (½)³ = 100 × 0.125 = 12.5 g remaining.

subtopic.name: Radioactive Decay and Half-Life
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the random nature of radioactive decay and how the half-life concept allows us to predict the behaviour of large numbers of radioactive nuclei. It includes mathematical modelling using whole half-lives.
subtopic.why: Half-life calculations are essential for applications ranging from carbon dating ancient objects to selecting appropriate radioisotopes for medical procedures and managing nuclear waste safely.

items.title: I can define and calculate the activity of a radioactive source
items.what: Activity is the number of nuclear decays per second, measured in becquerels (Bq), where 1 Bq = 1 decay per second. Activity decreases as the radioactive material decays, following the same half-life relationship.
items.why: Activity measures the current strength of a radioactive source, which determines its usefulness for applications and its radiation hazard level.
items.example: A cobalt-60 source has an initial activity of 440 TBq. After one half-life (5.27 years), its activity will be 220 TBq. After two half-lives, it will be 110 TBq.

subtopic.name: Radioactive Decay and Half-Life
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the random nature of radioactive decay and how the half-life concept allows us to predict the behaviour of large numbers of radioactive nuclei. It includes mathematical modelling using whole half-lives.
subtopic.why: Half-life calculations are essential for applications ranging from carbon dating ancient objects to selecting appropriate radioisotopes for medical procedures and managing nuclear waste safely.

items.title: I can determine the number of half-lives from remaining fraction
items.what: Working backwards from the fraction remaining, we can determine how many half-lives have elapsed. If ⅛ remains, that equals (½)³, so 3 half-lives have passed.
items.why: This skill is used in radiocarbon dating and other techniques to determine the age of samples by measuring how much radioactive material remains.
items.example: A bone sample contains ¼ of its original carbon-14. Since ¼ = (½)², two half-lives have elapsed. With carbon-14's half-life of 5730 years, the bone is about 11,460 years old.

subtopic.name: Radioactive Decay and Half-Life
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the random nature of radioactive decay and how the half-life concept allows us to predict the behaviour of large numbers of radioactive nuclei. It includes mathematical modelling using whole half-lives.
subtopic.why: Half-life calculations are essential for applications ranging from carbon dating ancient objects to selecting appropriate radioisotopes for medical procedures and managing nuclear waste safely.

items.title: I can explain why different radioisotopes are chosen for different applications
items.what: The half-life of a radioisotope determines its suitability for different uses. Medical tracers need short half-lives (hours to days), while smoke detectors need long half-lives (centuries).
items.why: Choosing the right half-life ensures the radioisotope remains useful for its intended purpose while minimising unnecessary radiation exposure.
items.example: Technetium-99m (6 hours) is ideal for medical scans as it decays quickly after imaging. Americium-241 (460 years) is used in smoke detectors so they never need isotope replacement.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the random nature of radioactive decay and how the half-life concept allows us to predict the behaviour of large numbers of radioactive nuclei. It includes mathematical modelling using whole half-lives.
subtopic.why: Half-life calculations are essential for applications ranging from carbon dating ancient objects to selecting appropriate radioisotopes for medical procedures and managing nuclear waste safely.

items.title: I can explain what a radioactive decay series represents
items.what: A decay series is the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy unstable nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope. Each decay produces a daughter nucleus that may itself be radioactive.
items.why: Decay series explain why uranium ore contains many different radioactive elements and why the heat from these decays keeps Earth's core molten.
items.example: Uranium-238 decays through 14 steps, producing thorium, protactinium, radium, radon, polonium, and bismuth isotopes before finally becoming stable lead-206.

subtopic.name: Decay Series Analysis
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how to read and interpret decay series diagrams that show the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope.
subtopic.why: Understanding decay series explains why mining uranium produces multiple radioactive substances and how heavy elements naturally transform into stable lead isotopes over geological time.

items.title: I can identify alpha decay on a decay series diagram
items.what: On decay diagrams, alpha decay appears as a diagonal arrow pointing left and down. The mass number decreases by 4 (moving down) and the atomic number decreases by 2 (moving left).
items.why: Recognising decay types on diagrams allows us to predict what daughter nucleus forms and write the corresponding decay equation.
items.example: On the uranium-238 decay diagram, the arrow from U-238 to Th-234 goes diagonally left, indicating alpha decay: ²³⁸₉₂U → ²³⁴₉₀Th + ⁴₂He.

subtopic.name: Decay Series Analysis
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how to read and interpret decay series diagrams that show the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope.
subtopic.why: Understanding decay series explains why mining uranium produces multiple radioactive substances and how heavy elements naturally transform into stable lead isotopes over geological time.

items.title: I can identify beta decay on a decay series diagram
items.what: On decay diagrams, beta-minus decay appears as a horizontal arrow pointing right. The mass number stays the same while the atomic number increases by 1.
items.why: Beta decay moves nuclei toward the belt of stability by changing the neutron-to-proton ratio without changing the total number of nucleons.
items.example: On the uranium-238 decay diagram, the arrow from Th-234 to Pa-234 goes horizontally right, indicating beta decay: ²³⁴₉₀Th → ²³⁴₉₁Pa + ⁰₋₁e.

subtopic.name: Decay Series Analysis
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how to read and interpret decay series diagrams that show the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope.
subtopic.why: Understanding decay series explains why mining uranium produces multiple radioactive substances and how heavy elements naturally transform into stable lead isotopes over geological time.

items.title: I can determine the stable end product of a decay series
items.what: Each natural decay series ends with a specific stable isotope of lead. The uranium-238 series ends at lead-206, the uranium-235 series ends at lead-207, and the thorium-232 series ends at lead-208.
items.why: Knowing the end product allows geologists to date rocks by measuring the ratio of parent to daughter isotopes and explains why lead is relatively abundant on Earth.
items.example: The uranium-238 decay series passes through 14 radioactive isotopes before terminating at stable lead-206, which has 82 protons and 124 neutrons.

subtopic.name: Decay Series Analysis
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how to read and interpret decay series diagrams that show the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope.
subtopic.why: Understanding decay series explains why mining uranium produces multiple radioactive substances and how heavy elements naturally transform into stable lead isotopes over geological time.

items.title: I can extract half-life information from decay series diagrams
items.what: Decay series diagrams typically show the half-life for each decay step. These range from microseconds (polonium-214: 160 μs) to billions of years (uranium-238: 4.5 × 10⁹ years).
items.why: Half-life information explains which daughter products accumulate in a sample and which decay almost immediately after being formed.
items.example: In the uranium-238 series, radium-226 has a half-life of 1600 years, long enough to accumulate in uranium ore, while polonium-214 (160 μs) decays almost instantly.

subtopic.name: Decay Series Analysis
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how to read and interpret decay series diagrams that show the sequence of radioactive decays a heavy nucleus undergoes until it reaches a stable isotope.
subtopic.why: Understanding decay series explains why mining uranium produces multiple radioactive substances and how heavy elements naturally transform into stable lead isotopes over geological time.

items.title: I can compare the ionising ability and penetrating power of alpha, beta, and gamma radiation
items.what: Alpha radiation has the highest ionising ability but lowest penetrating power. Gamma radiation has the lowest ionising ability but highest penetrating power. Beta radiation is intermediate for both properties.
items.why: These properties determine the hazard each radiation type poses and the shielding required for protection.
items.example: Alpha particles are stopped by paper or skin, beta particles by a few mm of aluminium, and gamma rays require about 5 cm of lead to absorb 97%.

subtopic.name: Radiation Effects and Applications
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how different types of radiation affect human cells, how radiation exposure is measured and quantified, and how radioisotopes are used in medical diagnosis and treatment.
subtopic.why: Understanding radiation effects is essential for radiation safety, setting exposure limits, and making informed decisions about medical procedures involving radiation.

items.title: I can explain the difference between external and internal radiation exposure
items.what: External radiation comes from sources outside the body, while internal radiation occurs when radioactive material is inhaled, ingested, or absorbed. The relative danger of each radiation type differs for external versus internal exposure.
items.why: Alpha radiation is relatively harmless externally but extremely dangerous internally, which is crucial for understanding radiation safety around contaminated materials.
items.example: Alpha-emitting radon gas is harmless outside the body but causes lung cancer when inhaled because alpha particles directly damage lung tissue.

subtopic.name: Radiation Effects and Applications
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how different types of radiation affect human cells, how radiation exposure is measured and quantified, and how radioisotopes are used in medical diagnosis and treatment.
subtopic.why: Understanding radiation effects is essential for radiation safety, setting exposure limits, and making informed decisions about medical procedures involving radiation.

items.title: I can describe short-term and long-term effects of radiation exposure
items.what: High doses (above 1 Sv) cause acute symptoms within days including nausea, vomiting, and hair loss. Lower doses may cause delayed effects like cancer appearing years or decades later.
items.why: Understanding dose-response relationships helps set safety limits and explains why both immediate and long-term monitoring is needed after radiation exposure.
items.example: Doses above 3-5 Sv cause 50% death rate within 1-2 months from bone marrow failure. Survivors face increased long-term risk of leukaemia and other cancers.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how different types of radiation affect human cells, how radiation exposure is measured and quantified, and how radioisotopes are used in medical diagnosis and treatment.
subtopic.why: Understanding radiation effects is essential for radiation safety, setting exposure limits, and making informed decisions about medical procedures involving radiation.

items.title: I can calculate absorbed dose in grays
items.what: Absorbed dose measures the energy deposited per kilogram of tissue. It is measured in grays (Gy), where 1 Gy = 1 J/kg. Absorbed dose = energy absorbed ÷ mass of tissue.
items.why: Absorbed dose quantifies the amount of radiation energy actually deposited in tissue, which is the starting point for assessing biological damage.
items.example: If a 2 kg tumour absorbs 0.01 J of gamma radiation, the absorbed dose is 0.01 J ÷ 2 kg = 0.005 Gy = 5 mGy.

subtopic.why: Understanding radiation effects is essential for radiation safety, setting exposure limits, and making informed decisions about medical procedures involving radiation.

items.title: I can calculate equivalent dose in sieverts using radiation weighting factors
items.what: Equivalent dose accounts for the different biological damage caused by each radiation type. It equals absorbed dose multiplied by the radiation weighting factor (1 for beta and gamma, 20 for alpha). Unit is sieverts (Sv).
items.why: The same absorbed dose causes different amounts of biological damage depending on radiation type, so equivalent dose allows comparison of health risks.
items.example: An absorbed dose of 5 mGy from gamma rays gives 5 mGy × 1 = 5 mSv equivalent dose. The same absorbed dose from alpha particles gives 5 mGy × 20 = 100 mSv.

subtopic.why: Understanding radiation effects is essential for radiation safety, setting exposure limits, and making informed decisions about medical procedures involving radiation.

items.title: I can explain how tissue weighting factors are used for effective dose
items.what: Different organs have different sensitivities to radiation damage. Effective dose uses tissue weighting factors to calculate whole-body risk when only certain organs are exposed.
items.why: This allows comparison of radiation risks when different organs are exposed, which is essential for planning medical procedures and setting occupational limits.
items.example: Lungs have a weighting factor of 0.12, while thyroid has 0.03. A lung dose is four times more likely to cause cancer than the same dose to the thyroid.

subtopic.why: Understanding radiation effects is essential for radiation safety, setting exposure limits, and making informed decisions about medical procedures involving radiation.

items.title: I can evaluate the use of radioisotopes in medical diagnosis and therapy
items.what: Medical diagnosis uses short-lived gamma emitters like technetium-99m to track body processes with minimal radiation exposure. Therapy uses targeted radiation to destroy cancer cells while minimising damage to healthy tissue.
items.why: Understanding the principles behind medical radiation use helps patients make informed decisions about diagnostic and treatment procedures.
items.example: Iodine-123 (gamma emitter, 13-hour half-life) is used to diagnose thyroid function, while iodine-131 (beta emitter, 8-day half-life) is used to destroy cancerous thyroid tissue.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers how different types of radiation affect human cells, how radiation exposure is measured and quantified, and how radioisotopes are used in medical diagnosis and treatment.
subtopic.why: Understanding radiation effects is essential for radiation safety, setting exposure limits, and making informed decisions about medical procedures involving radiation.

items.title: I can explain how radiation therapy targets cancer cells while protecting healthy tissue
items.what: Rapidly dividing cancer cells are more sensitive to radiation than normal cells. Treatment uses multiple low-dose beams from different angles that overlap only at the tumour, concentrating the dose where needed.
items.why: This principle allows doctors to deliver lethal doses to tumours while keeping surrounding healthy tissue exposure within acceptable limits.
items.example: Stereotactic radiosurgery uses 192 cobalt-60 gamma sources aimed at a brain tumour. Each beam delivers a low dose, but they all converge at the tumour for a high combined dose.
